events.summary: On a chilly December day, young Berlioz was born, making his first dramatic entrance into the world in La Côte-Saint-André. His arrival marked the beginning of a life filled with musical adventures, leading many to wonder if he'd ever follow in his father's medicinal footsteps.

Berlioz, having followed his father's medical dreams longer than most would tolerate, finally graduated in a field he had no intention of pursuing. He tossed his stethoscope aside to chase after symphonies instead - much to his father's dismay!

With high hopes and less-than-full pockets, Berlioz's music made its debut to an audience that didn't quite fill the seats. Nevertheless, the applause from fellow musicians was like a standing ovation, even if the attendance was more like a casual gathering.

In a twist of fate amid the revolutionary chaos, Berlioz dashed off the final notes of his winning cantata all while stray bullets sang a chaotic background melody. Nothing like a little gunfire to fuel creativity and win a prestigious music prize!

The grand premiere of his magnum opus, Symphonie fantastique, was a resounding hit, leaving audiences in shock and awe. With this piece, Berlioz solidified his status in the music world, confirming that he had indeed left the medic behind for good!

After an outstanding concert that showcased the innovative Symphonie fantastique, Berlioz made a lasting impression on Franz Liszt, marking the start of a friendship that could rival any romantic comedy.
In a fit of romantic despair after learning of Marie's new engagement, Berlioz fled from his studies in Rome faster than a cat from a bath, but luckily for him, he returned, much like a boomerang.
On a warm August day, the world welcomed Louis-Clément-Thomas, Berlioz's only child, who was presumably greeted with the same fanfare as a new symphony - though much less rehearsal was needed.
After a gripping performance of Harold in Italy, violin virtuoso Paganini was so moved he knelt and kissed Berlioz's hand, a gesture that surely made all those concerto performances worth it.

events.event: First performance of Roméo et Juliette
events.summary: The premiere of Roméo et Juliette had audiences in awe, leaving them with musical butterflies, and even Wagner was inspired to rethink his own compositions after witnessing Berlioz's genius at work.
In a bold move to become the orchestral guru of his time, Berlioz published his insights on orchestration, showing that he could whip up a music theory guide as easily as he composed symphonies.

Berlioz took his talents across the Rhine, conducting in German cities and charming audiences who appreciated his genius far more than those at home, making him feel like a rock star in a foreign land.

In a move that surprised absolutely no one, Berlioz decided to marry Marie Recio after living with her for years. It's like he finally realized that common-law marriage didn’t come with a tax break. This was a duty rather than a romantic revelation, but hey, at least the paperwork was sorted!

Berlioz wrapped up his sacred trilogy L'Enfance du Christ and was greeted with unexpected applause at its premiere. It was like ordering a salad at a burger joint and actually getting something decent!

events.event: Election to the Institut de France
events.summary: In a stroke of luck, Berlioz fulfilled a lifelong dream by being elected to the prestigious Institut de France. He played down the importance of it, but we all know he was secretly practicing his acceptance speech while trying not to lose his cool!

events.event: Staging of Les Troyens at Théâtre‐Lyrique
events.summary: Berlioz finally got to see his ambitious opera Les Troyens staged, after chopping it into two parts like a chef at a cooking show. The first part was presented with much fanfare, but darling, even that got sliced during its run. Talk about a less-is-more approach!

Berlioz faced another plot twist in his life story when his second wife passed away, leaving him not just heartbroken but also a bit more free time for long existential musings. It's the kind of turn of events that would make even a soap opera writer think twice!

In what can only be described as the ultimate tragedy bingo, Berlioz received word that his son had died of yellow fever. This news hit him harder than a flat tire on a road trip, turning his planned concerts into an uphill battle against sorrow.

Despite personal sorrow, Berlioz embarked on a planned tour of St Petersburg and Moscow, resulting in the kind of applause that might lead one to believe he knew all the right people in high places. However, the trip took more out of him than it gave back!

After an eventful life punctuated with triumphs and trials, Berlioz curled up for a long sleep that he wouldn't wake up from. He passed away in peace, hopefully with a satisfied grin, if not a last-minute composition waiting for critique!
Berlioz decided that classical norms were simply not enough; he crafted his first symphony, which was so unclassical that even Beethoven would have raised an eyebrow.
He gave the world 'Benvenuto Cellini', an opera that not even a time traveler from the future could believe would be a box office smash.
'Les Troyens', his magnum opus, hit the stage, making everyone wonder if they could sit through five hours of music, but hey, it was Berlioz, so why not?
In a grand gesture, Berlioz made waves with his 'Te Deum', showing off his penchant for the dramatic and leaving choirs scrambling for enough singers.
'Béatrice et Bénédict' was Berlioz's light-hearted nod to Shakespeare, proving he could also craft a comedy - and not just epic tragedies.
He released the '33 Mélodies', his final hurrah in music, leaving a collection that would have people pondering their unappreciated beauty for centuries to come.

Berlioz published a series of press columns in various significant journals, although he famously disliked writing them. He often joked that they stole precious time he'd rather spend composing actual music, turning him into a critic rather than a celebrated composer.

The first biography of Berlioz, authored by Eugène de Mirecourt, hit the shelves. It's unclear if Berlioz found it flattering or just another 'greatest hits' compilation of miscellaneous facts about his life and artistic struggles.
Berlioz's masterpiece, 'Symphonie Fantastique,' took center stage, leaving audiences either scratching their heads or dancing in the aisles – depending on how much coffee they had that day!
In a move that was as bold as his music, Berlioz married Harriet Smithson, the actress who inspired much of his work. Let's just say, their relationship had more drama than a typical opera!

Berlioz finally got to unleash his operatic talents with the premiere of 'Benvenuto Cellini.' Let's just say the audience would have needed a map to find their way around this complex tale of art and mischief!

An ambitious project, 'La Damnation de Faust,' hit the stage, and with it, Berlioz proved he was the master of musical storytelling, blending drama and creativity like a chef blends spices in a gourmet dish!
'Symphonie fantastique’ was born, a wild ride through the composer’s imagination where love and opium mingle in a hall of orchestral mirrors.
Berlioz scored a sweet gig with the prestigious Prix de Rome, leading him to a villa in Italy where he surely entertained his roommates with spontaneous symphonies.
The opera 'Benvenuto Cellini' debuted, allowing Berlioz a chance to showcase his avant-garde flair— and perhaps send a few audience members running for the exits.
Berlioz published his 'Treatise on Instrumentation', captivating readers with tips on how to use orchestral instruments to create crescendos that could make your ears tingle.
The grandiose opera 'Les Troyens' premiered, transforming stagecraft as Berlioz wove epic tales—complete with enough drama that you might need popcorn.

Chant des chemins de fer, H 110
Le dépit de la bergère, H 7
Grande symphonie funèbre et triomphale, H 80
Hymne pour la consécration du nouveau tabernacle, H 135
Lélio, ou le retour à la vie, H 55
Marche funèbre pour la dernière scène d'Hamlet, H 103
Quartetto e Coro dei Maggi, H 59
Sérénade agreste à la madone sur le thème des pifferari romains, H 98
Grand traité d'instrumentation et d'orchestration modernes, Op.10
